snippet: The former Communist states in Europe have seen a sharp rise in adult children living at home, but nothing like in Slovakia, where three out of four 18- to 34-year-olds live with their parents.
abstract: Slovakia, where 74 percent of adults 18 to 34 years old still live at home with their parents, is prime example in worldwide trend; phenomenon is particularly pronounced in former Communist states of Eastern Europe, where acute housing shortage has driven up rents.

byline.contributor: Miroslava Germanova contributed reporting from Trebisov, Slovakia.

lead_paragraph: The former Communist states in Europe have seen a sharp rise in adult children living at home, but nothing like in Slovakia, where three out of four 18- to 34-year-olds live with their parents.

headline.main: Empty Nest? In Slovakia, It May Begin When the Child Is 35
headline.print_headline: Empty Nest? Parents in Slovakia Needn’t Worry
